title: Perceived Neighborhood Safety and Active Transportation in Adults from Eight Latin American Countries
Finding 1: Variables related to crime and lighting of public spaces were associated with AT in countries in Latin America.

title: Cycling in sub-Saharan African cities: Differences and similarities with developed world cities
Finding 1: Studies in both developed world and SSA urban contexts point out that lack of street lighting can decrease the levels of cycling.

title: Perceived Safety and Security Barriers to Walking and Bicycling: Insights from Milwaukee
Finding 1: Both traffic safety concerns and personal security concerns were most strongly associated with poor neighborhood opportunities for exercise. Respondents living in lower-income communities reported greater barriers to pedestrian and bicycle safety and security than residents from wealthier neighborhoods.

title: Intelligent Nanoscopic Cyclist Crash Modelling for Variable Environmental Conditions
Finding 1: It is found that unsafeness of interaction between rider and infrastructure depends on lighting and road surface meteorological conditions.

title: Examining the state, quality and strength of the evidence in the research on built environments and physical activity among children and youth: An overview of reviews from high income countries
Finding 1: Less consistent positive associations were found for street lighting.

title: Road Safety Evaluation Framework for Accessing Park Green Space Using Active Travel
Finding 1: Nighttime brightness have pronounced effects on ATTS.

title: Crowdsourced Data for Physical Activity-Built Environment Research: Applying Strava Data in Chengdu, China
Finding 1: River line length and the light index have positive associations with running but not with cycling

title: Effect of Ambient Light on the Number of Motorized Vehicles, Cyclists, and Pedestrians
Finding 1: Darkness leads to significant reductions in pedestrians and cyclists but does not have a significant effect on the number of motorized vehicles

title: Extending observations of ambient light level and active travel to explore age and gender differences in reassurance
Finding 1: The deterrence of darkness was similar for males and females, which disagrees with previous studies

title: Environmental correlates of dock-less shared bicycle trip origins and destinations
Finding 1: Six factors are highly significant in higher uptake and deposit - the presence of a dedicated bicycle pathway, street lighting, sidewalks, bicycle parking lots, POI density, and street segment length

title: Impact of the built environment and the neighborhood in promoting the physical activity and the healthy aging in older people: An umbrella review
Finding 1: Elements positively associated with physical activity in older adults were (...) street lighting; crime-related safety; traffic-related safety. Negatively associated with physical activity were (…) barriers to walking/cycling; crime-related unsafety; unattended dogs; inadequate street lighting and upkeep; vandalism, etc.

title: Road lighting density and brightness linked with increased cycling rates after-dark
Finding 1: Locations with no road lighting showed a significantly greater reduction in cycling after-dark compared with locations that had some lighting. A nonlinear relationship was found between relative brightness at a location at night and the reduction in cyclists after-dark. Small initial increases in brightness resulted in large reductions in the difference between cyclist numbers in daylight and after-dark, but this effect reached a plateau as brightness increased.

title: Analysis of the impact of street-scale built environment design near metro stations on pedestrian and cyclist road segment choice: A stated choice experiment
Finding 1: pedestrians and cyclists have similar preferences for road segments with building lower than 6 floors, 50% retail shops in frontage, more greenery, lamps between 15 m and 30 m, more crossing facilities, wider sidewalk/bike lane and not crowded.

title: Bicycle facilities safest from crime and crashes: Perceptions of residents familiar with higher crime/lower income neighborhoods in Boston
Finding 1: Clean signs, balconies, cafes, street lights, no cuts between buildings, and flowers were low risk for crime and witnesses, little traffic, and bike signals low risk for crash.

title: A whole-year approach showing that ambient light level influences walking and cycling
Finding 1: The results confirm that ambient light has a significant impact: For a given time of day, more people walk or cycle when it is daylight than after dark and more people cycle on cycle trails and walk on foot paths after dark when they are lit than when they are unlit.

title: The impact of weather, road surface, time-of-day, and light conditions on severity of bicycle-motor vehicle crash injuries
Finding 1: Crashes in low light conditions and during early morning hours are more likely to result in higher injury severity.

title: A GPS data-based analysis of built environment influences on bicyclist route preferences
Finding 1: Some bicyclists favor routes which are planted with street trees or installed with street lights.

title: Using the daylight savings clock change to show ambient light conditions significantly influence active travel
Finding 1: Odds ratios indicated the numbers of pedestrians and cyclists during the case period were significantly higher during daylight conditions than after-dark, resulting in a 62% increase in pedestrians and a 38% increase in cyclists

title: The Influence of crime on active & sustainable travel: New geo-statistical methods and theories for understanding crime and mode choice
Finding 1: Violent crimes appear to significantly deter people from choosing to walk or bicycle, potentially exposing themselves to threats of personal injury

title: A pilot study of road lighting, cycle lighting and obstacle detection
Finding 1: The results suggest that when cycling on a lit road, cycle lighting frequently offers no benefit for peripheral detection and may make it worse. It was demonstrated that position matters.

title: Longitudinal associations between built environment characteristics and changes in active commuting
Finding 1: Those living in neighbourhoods with more streetlights were more likely to take up active commuting.

title: Lighting for cycling in the UK - A review
Finding 1: A number of actions are suggested that should enable lighting's contribution to the safety of cyclists to be realized.

title: The neighbourhood physical environment and active travel in older adults: A systematic review and meta-analysis
Finding 1: Positive associations were also observed with food outlets, business/institutional/industrial destinations, availability of street lights, easy access to building entrance and human and motorised traffic volume.

title: LED (Light-Emitting Diode) road lighting in practice: An evaluation of compliance with regulations and improvements for further energy savings
Finding 1: LED road lighting for vehicular traffic roads generally fulfilled the requirements, whereas that for pedestrian and bicycle roads generally corresponded to the lowest lighting class for L, and often did not meet the statutory requirements for Uo and UI.

title: Estimating welfare change associated with improvements in urban bicycling facilities
Finding 1: Cycle tracks were valued the most, followed by street lighting and bicycle lanes. Street lighting was valued much more than bicycle lanes, which are perhaps one of the most commonly added bicycle facilities. The results suggest that street lighting is something that future bicycle facility valuation and preference research should consider.

title: Influences of neighborhood crime on mode choice
Finding 1: This study found that high-crime neighborhoods tend to discourage residents from walking or riding a bicycle.

title: Neighbourhood design and physical activity
Finding 1: Respondents reported good lighting is the most important facilitator of walking and cycling.

title: Impact of an Adequate Road Environment on the Safety of Non-motorised Road Users
Identification of factors that influence cyclistś route choice
Route preferences among adults in the near market for bicycling: findings of the cycling in cities study
Built environment influences on healthy transportation choices: bicycling versus driving
Gender responsiveness in infrastructure provision for African cities: the case of Kampala in Uganda
Street visibility-dependent path finding for pedestrians and bicyclists in urban areas
Motivators and deterrents ofbicycling: comparinginfluences on decisions toride
BIKElife, All cities publication. Inclusive city cycling. Women: reducingthe gender gap
Physical environmental factors related to walking and cycling in older adults: the Belgian aging studies
Finding 1: The presence of street lighting increased the likelihood of daily cycling in < 75 years old females and rural females but not in other subgroups.

title: Day-to-Day Choice to Commute or Not by Bicycle
Finding 1: Women are less likely to cycle to work in the dark, so women are more sensitive to the absence of daylight.

title: Potential of transferring car trips to bicycle during winter
Finding 1: Darkness was also more important to women than to men, but with a mean grading of 3.0 in the survey of 1998, and 2.7 in the survey of 2000, this factor could still not, not even for women, be considered to be important in the choice of mode.

title: Influence of Individual Perceptions and Bicycle Infrastructure on Decision to Bike
Finding 1: Nightfall was more of a deterrent to bicycling than walking.
